The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. The present paper provides a categorical characterization of Hilbert space and the category of operators on it. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in these programs. The characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The paper also provides a categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert spaces. This is a significant advance because it is the first time that the category of Hilbert spaces has been characterized categorically.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To gain insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to successfully replicate and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. We further show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel (Hv1) is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. However, the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption varied from >99% to <1%. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which species can coexist.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and are closing. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but we find that many anticipate problems with accessing the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act should be complemented by grants to help small businesses survive the crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly because of size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global distribution of plastic debris in the ocean. It will be followed by a better quantification of the impacts of plastic debris on the marine ecosystem. This will be a key step toward the development of effective solutions to reduce the impact of plastic pollution.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of interstellar dust particles. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is in agreement with the age of the solar system. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We conclude that the solar system formed from the aggregation of interstellar dust particles. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This is important for the understanding of the early solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of animal societies. In this study, we show that the evolution of sociality has a strong effect on the reproductive output of mothers. We find that the evolution of sociality is associated with increased reproductive output, and that the most important factor limiting reproductive output is the mother’s metabolic power. Our results suggest that the evolution of sociality has had a strong effect on the evolution of placental mammals. This study also highlights the importance of allonursing in the evolution of sociality. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that is currently in clinical use, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to perform its many functions. This paper describes the nature of the communication network and how it is organized to efficiently control the functions of the endothelium. The findings are important for understanding the endothelium and its role in the cardiovascular system and in the body as a whole.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modelers. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers, and we hope that it will be useful to the research community and public health practitioners.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups and is associated with a variety of negative consequences. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of developing a subordinate status in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is essential for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are digitally synthesized through a free-form optimization approach. The synthesized structures are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors and seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The strategy can also be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and dynamic behaviors. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. It is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical devices with desired responses in various fields.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a critical component of the human body, providing oxygen transport in the blood. The Hb system is also a target of evolution, with the adult Hb system being the result of a process of evolution that occurred over millions of years. In this study, we investigated the role of a gene that is part of the evolution of the Hb system, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1). We found that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the developing human body and is down-regulated in the adult body. We also found that IGF2BP1 can affect the expression of the Hb system in the developing body. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a target for evolution of the Hb system. This study may also have implications for understanding the development of hemoglobinopathies. (Hemoglobinopathies are a group of genetic disorders that affect the Hb system.)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling through the STIM/ORAI pathway, which is up-regulated in hypertension. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This may help to reduce the risk of adverse cardiovascular events. (Read more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has not yet been sufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has been stable, but the number of early-seral bird species has declined. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management, which are central to the NWFP.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a challenging task, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end since they enable fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, making it easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations and is able to adapt to different problems. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is simple to implement, train, and apply in practice. It is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems. The proposed architecture is available for download. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for the community.

Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the development of sleep hygiene guidelines. They also highlight the need for further research into the effects of electronic devices on sleep and health. (Show more)

The cause of the abrupt climate change at the end of the last Ice Age is a matter of debate. One hypothesis is that a bolide impact triggered the change. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In addition, the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotope compositions of a rare 2- to 5-mm diameter spherule indicate that it formed in the Quebecia terrain of 1.5 Ga. The spherule is likely ejecta from an impact 12.9 ka ago. The Os in the spherule is likely terrestrial. These results support the impact hypothesis. (Read more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to the development of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be prevented by Treg cell-mediated suppression. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 expression in the thymus is essential for the development of autoimmunity. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which are the basis of all known beetle feeding habits. Our results show that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes enabled the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring, and that these genes were key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-SeekBar virus variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the evolution of the Earth. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the most stable phase of iron at high pressure and temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its evolution. (Show more)

The use of marijuana has increased dramatically in the United States, and the drug is now legal in some form in 29 states. The legal status of marijuana has led to a lack of research on the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. We found that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. The reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and it is possible that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate contributes to the increased addiction and negative emotionality in marijuana abusers.

Language is the most complex behavior evolved in human history. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive science. Here, we show that the most accurate deep learning models of language comprehension also predict brain activity and behavior in this domain. Our results provide computational evidence for a key mechanism in the language comprehension circuit in the human brain: predictive processing. These findings are a first step toward understanding the brain’s mechanism for generating language. They also have implications for understanding the origins of language and for building artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a fundamental problem but rather a consequence of the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are unstable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can compute stable neural networks with great accuracy. This theory will help us understand the limits of stability in DL and will be useful for the development of more stable DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This paper shows that the “classic” experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon is not only flawed but also supports the opposite conclusion. The paper discusses the implications of this unique case study for the study of human cognition and the interpretation of scientific evidence.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for different forms of the disease. The former causes the loss of sensation in the face, whereas the latter causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are very similar, and that they have retained the ability to cause leprosy in the nervous system. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease in the 21st century.

The evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question in the field of quantum information and condensed matter physics. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of entanglement in quantum quenches. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our results against numerical simulations and show that they are valid for a wide class of models. Our results are relevant for the understanding of the evolution of entanglement in quantum quenches and for the description of the evolution of entanglement in the presence of interactions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a vaccine is needed that is safe, effective, and easily administered. Here, we describe a vaccine that is safe, effective, and easily administered. The vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS-CoV-2 virus that is highly attenuated and can be easily manufactured in large quantities. The vaccine is able to protect hamsters from the virus and, upon challenge, is able to protect them from the disease. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that is still a threat to human health, as evidenced by the recent outbreaks in Central Asia. In this study, we developed a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study may help to understand the history of plague and to predict the potential impact of future outbreaks. It may also help to develop strategies for the control of future plague epidemics.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neuroanatomy. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the product of both size and number of neurons, has been less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain power in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts. The first two shifts are related to the evolution of birds and mammals, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. The other two shifts are related to the evolution of core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive abilities. These results have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study may help to clarify the role of TRAP1 in cancer and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key component of many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, how ADF/cofilin regulates actin filament disassembly is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can induce the mechanical twisting of actin filaments, which enhances severing of filament networks. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in many cellular processes. They also have implications for understanding the role of actin filaments in many biological processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cytokinesis. Our findings may also have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in many diseases, including cancer.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related metabolic disorders. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. The findings may also have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for the genetic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a key population for the study of human evolution and adaptation. It will also be a valuable resource for the study of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people experience the same emotions without their awareness. We show that this occurs even when people are not directly interacting with each other, and even when they are not aware of the emotions being transferred. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms. It also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and it is well established that chemical modifications of the RNA can affect the translation rate and the protein product. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on the ribosome itself has been less well studied. Here, we show that the presence of a chemical modification in the mRNA sequence can affect the ribosome’s ability to translate. We find that the modification of a single uridine nucleotide in the mRNA sequence can affect the ribosome’s ability to translate and the rate at which it synthesizes a protein. Our work suggests that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can affect the ribosome’s function and that this can have important implications for the translation of the mRNA. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better physical and mental health, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, sex, and educational attainment. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving mammals toward a common size attractor. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity may help explain its high incidence. We show that the mouse airway epithelium, a relevant model for the upper respiratory tract, replicates rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the type I IFN response and may contribute to the high incidence of rhinovirus infection. These findings may help to identify new targets for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

The ability to sense the environment and respond appropriately is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense the environment and respond accordingly. This mechanism is based on the type IV pili, a major surface-adhesion system of this pathogen, which are used to sense the environment and regulate the activity of a chemosensory system that regulates the production of the bacterial virulence factor cAMP. This system is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacterium to sense the environment and respond appropriately. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense the environment and respond accordingly. Understanding how bacteria sense and respond to the environment is important for understanding how bacteria adapt to their environment and how this adaptation contributes to the pathogenesis of bacterial infections. This study also provides a model for how bacteria can use their surface-adhesion system to sense the environment and respond accordingly. This model can be applied to other bacteria and may provide a way to understand how bacteria adapt to their environment and how this adaptation contributes to the pathogenesis of bacterial infections.
