The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous period, raises questions about the early evolution of these plants. Montsechia is a plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum, but it is sister to Ceratophyllum and eudicots. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolution of the most common human pathogen, human parvovirus B19 (B19V). Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype, genotype 2, occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results show that ancient viral sequences are important for understanding the evolution of viruses. This study also emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This rate is 1.5 times larger than the rate of sea level rise over the last century. This paper also provides a new estimate of the rate of climate change in sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.43 ± 0.12 mm/y2. This rate is 1.5 times larger than the rate of climate change in sea level rise over the last century.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of enzyme mechanisms is a relatively new field, and the study of the active site of tryptophan synthase, a prototypical β-elimination and replacement reaction enzyme, provides a unique opportunity to study the dynamics of the active site and the role of the cofactor in the mechanism of such a reaction. The results of this study provide a detailed picture of the active site and the role of the cofactor in the mechanism of this enzyme. This study highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a severe and poorly understood human coronavirus infection. The development of effective antiviral treatments is therefore of critical importance. Here, we report the results of a study in nonhuman primates that tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a drug that has shown promising results in vitro and in vivo against SARS-CoV. Remdesivir treatment was effective in preventing the development of clinical disease and in reducing the severity of lung lesions. These results support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. The data presented here may also be relevant for the emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is synchronized with the host’s circadian clock. We propose that this strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes.

In the United States, suspension rates are high and growing. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this change can reduce suspension rates. The study also shows that an intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic mindset can reduce suspension rates. These findings have implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of how alkylated DNA lesions affect the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylated DNA lesions on the transcription process. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the presence of alkylated DNA lesions. The transcription process is affected by the presence of alkylated DNA lesions in two ways: (i) the transcription process is stalled at the alkylated DNA lesion, and (ii) the transcription process is affected by the presence of alkylated DNA lesions in the minor groove. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the impact of alkylated DNA lesions on the transcription process. This work will help us to understand the impact of alkylated DNA lesions on the genome stability and cancer development. This work will also help us to develop new strategies for the development of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV virulence. The first S proteolysis expands virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large impact on these emissions, and the food system is the largest contributor to greenhouse gas emissions in the UK. The food system also has a large impact on the health of the population, and the food choices of the population have a large impact on health. The food system is also a major contributor to biodiversity loss. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a large impact on the health of the population and the environment. This is a simple intervention that can be implemented in many settings.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the cell surface proteome is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has spread rapidly and is highly infectious, leading to a need for a rapid and accurate diagnostic test. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the COVID-19 disease and may lead to the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is known to cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to activation of astrocytes, which in turn release endothelin-1 (ET-1), which causes edema. These findings provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to make false claims about the ones that are not important. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help readers to understand the strengths and limitations of these methods.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel wall, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, such as atherosclerosis and stroke. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of ligand-activated RTKs has revolutionized our understanding of the biology of these proteins. In this study, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) with their ligands. We show that augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our results provide insights into the function of these orphan RTKs and their ligands in vivo. They also provide a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs in general. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well-known, the molecular bases of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, we established that STING is required for normal β-cell function and is involved in the regulation of insulin secretion. These findings provide a better understanding of the pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These data also suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which favors their preferential packaging into each virion. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent strains is limited. Our results provide a molecular understanding of the packaging process and could be used to develop new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. En face analysis of mouse arteries demonstrated an increased nuclear localization of YAP/TAZ and elevated levels of the target genes in the endothelium in atheroprone

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work is a step towards the development of a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms that drive the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and the collapse of coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and other diseases

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in the United States and worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. We found that breast cancer cells express the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1, and that ROR1 expression is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event was instead triggered by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a large increase in surface UV radiation. These changes, in turn, likely led to a change in Southern Hemisphere circulation and climate, which is consistent with the timing of the deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and ecosystem services. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on inland fisheries makes them vulnerable to the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and the sustainability of fisheries. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries management is needed to protect food security and biodiversity. This will be particularly important in the face of climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency and severity of droughts and floods.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the well-characterized signaling pathways that mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by activating a second form of regeneration that is triggered by sensory activity. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Our study also suggests that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought in its ability to regenerate.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, but the rate of recombination between homologous chromosomes during meiosis is a major determinant of the rate of evolution. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing no recombination at all. The distribution of recombination is strikingly similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The brain is a dynamic system, and the study of its functional organization requires the use of time-series analysis. The analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity, has led to the identification of resting state networks (RSNs). The present study provides a validation of the RSN concept by showing that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. In PD, the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest, whereas in healthy subjects and early PD patients it was activated. In Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant RSN was deactivated at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct link between the functional and metabolic organization of the brain. They also provide a framework for the study of the functional significance of the observed changes.

The 5′ cap structure is the most prominent modification of mRNA and is essential for efficient translation. In bacteria, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group is found on tRNA and rRNA, but the presence of NAD+ on mRNAs has not been reported. Here we show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. We propose that the NAD+ cap is a new modification of eukaryotic mRNA and that it may play a role in regulating translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The mechanisms behind metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and provide a potential target for therapeutic intervention.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and for the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in TNBC and may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The causes of this disorder are not fully understood, but it is generally accepted that it is a brain disorder. In the present study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop a leaky gut, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a key element in the development of the disorder and in the maintenance of the symptoms.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of 2-substituted tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid substrates into the corresponding volatiles. This pathway is unique to tomato fruit and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. This study provides a major advance in our understanding of tomato flavor and lays the foundation for the development of improved varieties with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changes in response to temperature, and that this change is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of global warming in the context of biodiversity loss, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains two types of neurons that are thought to be essential for navigation: grid cells and border, head-direction (HD), and object-vector (OV) cells. Grid cells are thought to be the primary map of local space, while border, HD, and OV cells are thought to be the primary map of direction and heading. We used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. Our data suggest that grid cells are not only spatially organized but also strongly coupled among themselves, while border, HD, and OV cells are not strongly coupled to each other. These results have implications for understanding the organization of the navigation system. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host plant and the dodder parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model for understanding the evolution of flowering in plants. (Show more)

The dopamine system of the brain is involved in movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro–striato–nigral loop form a specialized system that is disrupted in human disorders. Within this system, we identify a unique formation of dopamine-containing neurons that receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and project to regions involved in decision-making and reward. These striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system and could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly organized network of cells that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of these cells by modulating the activity of calcium channels. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provide a molecular mechanism for how STIM1 may influence the electrical activity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the role of Si in plant resistance against biotic and abiotic stresses has been well documented, the function of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), two key enzymes in JA biosynthesis and perception, respectively. These results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses is a key mechanism underlying the Si-enhanced resistance against insect herbivores. Our findings provide insights into the underlying mechanisms of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores. These results may also have implications for the development of sustainable agricultural practices to improve crop productivity and reduce the use of chemical pesticides. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is simple and can account for a number of observations. It is also biologically plausible, as it does not require the involvement of inhibitory feedback or synaptic plasticity. We show that this mechanism can support memory for information over a range of timescales, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that can be tested in future experiments. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language in other species.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of functional biomolecules to plants is challenging due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall and into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are critical design parameters for the successful delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall and corresponding gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide, and it is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on the largest watersheds, despite the fact that small tributaries are ubiquitous and can be the most important sources of nutrients to coastal areas. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include small watersheds, as they may play a disproportionate role in driving coastal eutrophication. This could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We show that the saddle-node bifurcation is a generic feature of the dynamics of this network, and we discuss the implications of this finding for the study of complex systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We use a dynamic causal model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain the EEG paroxysms in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these changes in the network are sufficient to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab and may help to inform the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a large injection of organic matter–derived carbon and widespread seafloor anoxia. The warming event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during an icehouse climate. Our study highlights the potential for abrupt warming events to have a large impact on the Earth system and to have important implications for the future of our planet.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the proper functioning of all kingdoms of life. In humans, the exocyst complex is involved in the development of cancer and diabetes. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in the development of flowers and fruits. The exocyst complex is composed of 14 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that a small molecule binds to one of the subunits of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination genes in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple genes can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the addition of a new sex determination gene can produce even more variation in secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating products of metabolism and photooxidation. The retina also contains iron, which is essential for redox reactions but can be toxic in excess. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone reduces the photooxidation of the bisretinoid A2E in the retina and protects photoreceptor cells from light-induced death. These findings suggest that Fe may be a target for therapeutic intervention in retinal disease. This interpretation is supported by the demonstration that the Fe chelator also reduces the photooxidation of A2E in cell-free assays. These results are important for understanding the role of Fe in the retina and for developing therapeutic strategies for retinal disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. In this study, we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators has been shaped by the diversification of prey types. Our results show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. We show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived hand feature in modern humans and Neandertals, was present ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the potential for fossils from East Africa to provide important insights into the evolution of the hominin hand. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) provides these units, but cancer cells have evolved to have high levels of the enzyme, which is why it has been a target for cancer therapy. Here we show that a small molecule that inhibits SHMT in normal cells also inhibits SHMT in cancer cells, and that this inhibition leads to cell death. We also show that cancer cells have a unique metabolic defect that makes them dependent on SHMT activity to meet their demand for one-carbon units. Thus, targeting SHMT in cancer cells may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely appreciated. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new field of research and one that is likely to become increasingly important in the future.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest animals that walked Earth. This study shows that the weight of farm machinery has contributed to a global trend of subsoil compaction, with the risk of subsoil compaction now affecting 20% of arable land. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
